title-group.article-title: An Overview of Principles for Special Educators to Guide Mathematics Instruction

author-notes.corresp: Delinda van Garderen, Department of Special Education, University of Missouri, 303 Townsend Hall (office in 311k Townsend), Columbia, MO 65211, USA Email: vangarderend@missouri.edu

abstract.p: Teaching mathematics to diverse learners can be a challenge. The extensive and specialized knowledge that special education teachers need to possess to be considered high-quality teachers is often lacking in preservice and inservice education, yet is mandated by current teacher reforms and rigorous measures of accountability. To provide direction for supporting teacher growth in these areas, this article highlights four knowledge bases that special education teachers should develop and expand upon as a way to improve their instruction for diverse learners in mathematics. Numerous resources and materials are provided to support the development of teacher expertise in content, characteristics of diverse learners, technology, and pedagogy.

body.p: Mathematics education reform emphasizes excellence and equity for all students (e.g., National Governors Association Center for Best Practices, Council of Chief State School Officers, 2010; National Council of Teachers of Mathematics [NCTM], 2000; National Mathematics Advisory Panel [NMAP], 2008). Furthermore, both the Individuals With Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEIA; 2004) and the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB; 2002) underscore the need for access to the general education curriculum as well as more rigorous standards for students with disabilities and their teachers (Common Core State Standards Initiative, 2010). Despite the greater recognition of the need for high expectations for all students, diverse learners continue to underperform in mathematics (e.g., National Assessment of Educational Progress [NAEP], National Center for Education Statistics, [NCERS], 2009, Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study [TIMSS], Gonzales et al., 2008). Underachievement in mathematics is particularly severe for diverse learners, including those with disabilities, English language learners (ELL), and students from low socioeconomic (SES) backgrounds (Gonzales et al. 2008; NCERS, 2009, 2011). Moreover, the significance and persistence of underachievement in mathematics is reflected in the TIMSS data demonstrating that there has been relatively little change in scores from 2003 to 2007 in spite of reform efforts (Gonzales et al., 2008).

Given the expectations for higher achievement in mathematics and the continued achievement difficulties diverse students’ experience, there is a need for special education teachers to have strategies that they can utilize to support learners in these areas. This article provides special educators with information and evidence-based practices to more effectively teach mathematics to increase student success. As schools are increasingly utilizing a multitiered prevention model within a response to intervention (RTI) framework, this article focuses on diverse learners including students with learning disabilities as well students without identified learning disabilities who are struggling and need more support.

sec.title: What Should Special Educators Know to Teach Mathematics?
sec.p: The quality of special education teachers and their impact on student performance is currently a critical focus for funding, research, and evaluation (American Association of College Teachers [AACTE] Teacher Performance Assessment Consortium, n.d.; Drame & Pugach, 2010; Sindelar, Brownell, & Billingsley, 2010). Unfortunately, special educators’ preparation to teach mathematics is of particular concern. There is strong evidence to suggest that teachers, including special education teachers, lack sufficient mathematical content knowledge (e.g., Ball, Thames, & Phelps, 2008; Borko, 2004). Many teachers have a poor understanding of teaching and learning for specific content areas, which can result in (a) an overemphasis on teaching procedural, lower-level skills and (b) poor use of materials (Griffin, Jitendra & League, 2009; Maccini & Gagnon, 2002; van Garderen, 2008). The challenge, then, is finding ways to help special educators identify and develop a sufficient knowledge base in mathematics.

Guidelines, principles, and standards to direct instructional practices have been proposed by various councils in general and special education. However, these are not specific to the needs of students with disabilities in academic content areas (Council for Exceptional Children [CEC], 2008; NCTM, 2000). Brownell, Sindelar, Kiely, and Danielson (2010) discussed the minimum content special educators should know to be “quality” teachers. They noted, “Special education teachers must demonstrate, at minimum, a sophisticated knowledge base that extends beyond that of general education teachers, and this expertise must add value to the general education that students with disabilities receive” (p. 371). They suggested that there are at least four well-integrated knowledge bases that special education teachers need, including
understanding of (a) content and how to teach it, (b) specific problems that students with disabilities may experience in a particular content area, (c) the role of technology in circumventing learning issues or supporting access to more sophisticated learning, and (d) the role of specific interventions and assessments in providing more intensive, explicit instruction within a broader curricular context. (p. 369)

These four key knowledge areas provide an excellent framework that can be used to highlight a summary of the types of strategies and methods special educators should know for teaching mathematics to diverse students (see Figure 1). Information about specific evidence-based practices in mathematics instruction is provided (see Table 1), and an array of resources to support teacher development are presented as well (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Selected resources and materials recommended to support development of teacher knowledge for each of the four knowledge bases.

sec.title: Content Knowledge
sec.p: Recent studies (Brownell et al., 2009; Hill et al., 2008) suggest that the domain expertise (i.e., knowledge of a discipline and how students build knowledge within it) possessed by a teacher is closely connected to both teaching and student learning. Effective teachers, therefore, not only have knowledge of the subject matter but are also able to use that knowledge successfully to respond to students’ diverse needs (Haager, Gersten, Baker, & Graves, 2003; Seo, Brownell, Bishop, & Dingle, 2008). In addition, research on teaching and learning in mathematics suggests that effective instruction includes components such as

list-item.p: Conceptual understanding, which includes knowledge about the relationship of the mathematical concepts, operations and relations of a topic;
Strategic competence, which is the ability to formulate, represent, and solve problems;
Adaptive reasoning, which is the use of logical thought, reflection, explanation, and justification to solve problems;
Productive dispositions, which includes seeing mathematics as sensible, useful, and worthwhile along with a belief in one’s own ability and efficacy to do mathematics; and
Procedural fluency, which is the having skills to carry out procedures flexibly, accurately, efficiently and appropriately (NCTM, 2000; NRC, 2001).

sec.p: Furthermore, this instruction is to be balanced with respect to the types of knowledge to be mastered. For example, a focus in computation would be on both developing procedural fluency (e.g., knowledge of the rules and procedures for carrying out an addition problem) as well as conceptual understanding (e.g., knowledge about the relationships or foundational ideas of what it means to add; Van de Walle, Karp, & Bay-Williams, 2010). As another example, a focus in solving word problems would be on developing strategic competence (e.g., using a representation such as a diagram to both understand and solve a problem; van Garderen, 2006) as well as adaptive reasoning (e.g., recognition of when and where to apply a strategy to solve different problem types; Fuchs, Fuchs, Hamlett, & Appleton, 2002).

Most importantly, knowledge of the content itself is critical. Understanding the content is crucial in order for special educators to identify key concepts to be focused on during instruction, develop a program that follows a good sequence and scope, and provide a balanced program (Parmar & Cawley, 1997). For example, central to early mathematical development for students is the idea of number sense (Gersten & Chard, 1999). Some might narrowly define number sense as computation. However, number sense as a concept covers a broad range of constructs such as conservation of quantity, magnitude, subsidizing, and order irrelevance, each of which needs to be understood in order to be applied at the level of instruction (Clements, 2007; Fosnot & Dolk, 2001).

sec.title: Learner Characteristics
sec.p: Recently, research on learning and disability has grown both in volume and in sophistication (Brownell et al., 2010). Teachers need to understand how these difficulties present themselves and impact learning to provide appropriate, targeted instruction. For example, Johnson, Humphrey, Mellard, Woods, and Swanson (2010) highlight several findings regarding key deficit characteristics of students with learning disabilities in cognitive processes that may hinder learning in mathematics, such as (a) verbal working memory, (b) visual working memory, (c) processing speed, (d) attention, and (e) executive function. Each process appears to be related to specific difficulties students may experience with math fact fluency (Geary, Brown, & Samaranayake, 1991), problem solving, and number sense (Geary, 2004).

Research also suggests that a possible contributor to the mathematics difficulties students with disabilities experience relates to poor numerosity, in particular, a “number module deficit” (Landerl, Bevan, & Butterworth, 2004; Rousselle & Noël, 2007). Butterworth (2005) and Landerl et al. (2004) proposed that this deficit may result in difficulty understanding critical number concepts such as magnitude, counting difficulties, number reading, number comparison, and, as a result, in learning numerical information in general. Interestingly, findings from a recent study conducted by Rousselle and Noël (2007) suggest that, in part, the difficulty children may experience with numerical symbols (magnitude) is related to poor understanding of their underlying meaning rather than difficulties in fact retrieval.

Students with learning disabilities and those who struggle due to other risk factors also have additional characteristics that affect their ability to be successful in math. Risk characteristics that need to be considered include, for example, attention issues, impulsivity, language deficits, hyperactivity, lack of prior knowledge or fluency with specific skills, memory difficulties, and motivation problems (Stormont, 2007). These characteristics create needs for both frequent assessment because of limited prior knowledge or fluency and additional supports such as frequent but distributed practice (due to attention problems) and connecting the importance of content to everyday life (to increase motivation). Teachers can plan their curriculum and instruction for the characteristics their particular learners’ manifest and utilize technological resources to assist them in meeting their needs. The importance of technology knowledge and utilization is discussed in the next section, followed by evidence-based practices that are effective given they include components that attend to the needs of students with learning disabilities and those who are at risk in math.

sec.title: Technological Knowledge
sec.p:
Significant advancements in technology have been made, and these innovations hold tremendous potential for improving the education of students struggling in math (see Figure 2 for resources). In a position statement, The Role of Technology in the Teaching and Learning of Mathematics, NCTM (2008) states,
Technology is an essential tool for learning mathematics in the 21st century, and all schools must ensure that all their students have access to technology. Effective teachers maximize the potential of technology to develop students’ understanding, stimulate their interest, and increase their proficiency in mathematics. When technology is used strategically, it can provide access to mathematics for all students.

In the report Learning Technology, the Office of Educational Technology (Atkins et al., 2010) called for application of learning sciences and technology to enhance mathematics education. Low-tech, mid-tech, and high-tech devices—including calculators, computers, tablets, and software such as graphing and statistical programs—are all increasing engagement and learning for today’s students (Atkins et al., 2010; Hasselbring, Lott, & Zydney, 2006). For example, calculators, including computer-based, online, and talking versions, can provide support for students with working memory deficits and/or processing speed deficits; producing the accuracy and speed required with facts and computations to enable access to instruction in higher level critical thinking and problem solving in math. Graphic organizers, including online versions, create visual displays of mathematical information, making complex data accessible by helping students focus attention on critical information such as relationships and concepts. Graphic displays employ recommendations from the learning sciences that enable coding of information through multiple representations, increasing the probability of effective storage and retrieval in memory (Committee on Developments in the Science of Learning, National Research Council, & Commission on Behavioral and Social Sciences in Education, 2000; Mayer, 2011). Technology tools can be assistive (Alper & Raharinirina, 2006; Bouck & Flanagan, 2009), remedial (Hasselbring et al., 2006), and/or compensatory (Patton & Roschelle, 2008).

Universal design for learning (UDL; Patton & Roschelle, 2008) and the use of accessible instructional materials (National Center on Accessible Instructional Materials at CAST, 2011) have become increasingly important in the provision of mathematics instruction. UDL is a framework for curriculum design that removes barriers to learning by planning from the outset to include multiple means of representation, expression, and engagement and to use technology to promote access to the general curriculum for all students, including students who struggle in math. Accessible instructional materials (AIM) use technology to remove barriers for students with print disabilities, including students with sensory, physical, and intellectual disabilities. The role of reading and language in math success is often underestimated, and AIM provide math content using Braille, audio files, text to speech options, and so forth (U.S. Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights, 2011). Technology offers powerful affordances that provide access to the general curriculum for diverse learners (Atkins et al., 2010; Hasselbring et al., 2006).

sec.title: Pedagogical Knowledge
sec.p: A central role of special educators is to provide interventions and assessment to diverse learners. Special education teachers must be knowledgeable about evidence-based intervention strategies that address the specific needs of diverse learners (CEC, 2008). As Brownell et al. (2010) noted, “Unlike we imagined in previous eras, the diagnostic and intervention knowledge of special education teachers must be well integrated with content domain knowledge” (p. 369).

Many studies over the past 20 years have been conducted to determine intervention strategies that work for students with diverse needs. Admittedly, the majority of studies have been conducted in reading, with fewer in mathematics (e.g., see recent reviews by Gersten et al., 2009; Newman-Gonchar, Clarke, & Gersten, 2009; NMAP, 2008). However, several chapters and reports have been published in the past few years that can help direct best practices in mathematics (Stormont, Reinke, Herman, & Lembke, 2012). Several principles of instruction, intervention programs that can be applied to any topic area, and strategies for targeted content areas and topics have been identified that should be used when teaching mathematics to diverse learners. Furthermore, a hallmark of special education is the use of assessment to guide instruction; accordingly, evidence-based formative assessment practices in mathematics are critical. Recently, multitiered systems such as RTI have emphasized the need to use assessment to identify student needs and then systematically deliver interventions of the appropriate intensity and duration to remediate specific skill deficits (Gersten et al., 2009). When special education teachers are in schools implementing RTI, they may have more support for using the following recommended practices.

sec.title: Evidence-based practices in mathematics
sec.p: Research in the area of effective mathematics instruction for diverse learners and those with learning disabilities underscores the importance of several key practices. These practices include (Gersten et al., 2009; Stormont et al., in press) the following:

list-item.p: Explicit and systematic instruction with guided practice, corrective feedback, frequent cumulative review;
Use of visual representations (e.g., number lines, graphs, drawings of objects, or tallies);
Use of motivational strategies (e.g., making connections to real-world content);
Support for problem solving through instruction on specific strategies and when to use them;
Systematic assessment of student progress; and
Opportunities to practice basic facts and algorithms to build fluency.

sec.p: Table 1 includes an overview of specific programs and practices that have been demonstrated as effective for learners with learning disabilities and/or those who struggle in math. Specific examples of intervention programs that are evidence-based in mathematics and include systematic and explicit lesson plan frameworks include Hot Math and Peer-Assisted Learning Strategies (PALS) in Mathematics. Hot Math (Fuchs, Fuchs, Prentice, Burch, & Paulsen, 2002) is a structured intervention that can be used as a whole class or small group tutoring intervention and focuses on explicit instruction and self-regulation strategies. PALS math (Fuchs, Fuchs, Yazdian, & Powell, 2002; http://www.kc.vanderbilt.kennedy/pals) is an evidence-based, classwide tutoring method that has been researched with students at risk, with disabilities, and with ELLs, at both elementary and secondary levels. Both Hot Math and PALS can be implemented during general classroom instruction, with the general education and special education teachers collaborating to serve all students.

With respect to more specific strategies in the content areas, including mathematics, whole class and individually or small group–applied strategies are supported by research (see Table 1). Examples of these include the following:

list-item.p: Schema-based instruction (Jitendra et al., 1998) is a well-researched practice in which students learn to recognize problem types for word problems (e.g., additive, multiplicative, and vary problem structures), diagram the problem type, determine the math operation associated with the problem type, and compute the problem.

Cognitive strategy instruction (e.g., Solve It!) was developed by Montague (1992, 2003). Students are taught seven cognitive processes and strategies (e.g., read, paraphrase, visualize, hypothesize, estimate, compute, and check) to solve word problems.

Concrete-Representational-Abstract is an instructional sequence to teach specific mathematical concepts and skills such as addition with regrouping, subtraction with regrouping, coin sums, place value, multiplication, algebra, and geometry to students with disabilities (Cass, Cates, Smith, & Jackson, 2003; Miller, Kaffar, & Mercer, 2012; Miller & Mercer, 1998; Miller, Mercer, & Dillon, 1992; Witzel, Smith, & Brownell, 2001).

Cover, Copy, and Compare presents students with an arithmetic fact (e.g., 3 + 4 = 7), which they look at, cover, and write an equation for the fact; they then compare their written equation to the original example. If the written response matches the model, students then move on to the next fact (McLaughlin & Skinner, 1996; Skinner, Ford, & Yunker, 1991).

sec.title: Formative assessment in math
sec.p: To attain successful results from intervention implementation, interventions need to be implemented with integrity, and intervention progress needs to be evaluated formatively. One type of formative evaluation that has been strongly supported in the literature is curriculum-based measurement (CBM; see Deno, 1985, 2003). A CBM includes measures that are reliable and valid indicators of a particular subject and are efficient, easy to administer, and standardized. In the area of mathematics, CBMs have been developed in areas such as early numeracy (e.g., number identification, quantity discrimination), computation, concepts and applications, and algebra. (See Foegen, Jiban, and Deno, 2007 for a comprehensive review of measures in mathematics.) These mathematics measures generally take between 2 and 8 minutes to administer and can be administered in a group setting.

Curriculum-based measurement can be utilized for both screening and progress monitoring. When used for screening, measures are traditionally administered three times during the year to all students to identify students who might be at-risk. This identification process occurs as a result of examining all student scores and determining which students have the lowest percentages, or by comparing individual student’s results to already existing norms for the measures. Progress monitoring occurs on a frequent basis for students who are low-achieving. Once interventions are put into place, student progress is monitored on a frequent basis (most often weekly), and data are graphed and compared to a goal line. Decision-making rules are established so that teachers can examine the graphed data and determine if students are exceeding, meeting, or not meeting the individual goal that was set. These decision-making rules help teachers determine if intervention is effective and give teachers guidance about when instructional changes need to be made (Deno, 1985). There are many resources available to support teachers in their use of CBM including commercially available systems like Easy CBM (http://easyCBM.com), Aimsweb (http://www.aimsweb.com), Yearly Progress Pro (http://www.ctb.com), and Monitoring Basic Skills Progress (MBSP; proedinc.com).

Teacher-made tests can also be developed to systematically probe for understanding. It is essential that assessments clearly target skills students are working on and that teachers assess often in order to inform instruction (Stormont, 2007). Assessment can also be used to conduct error analyses to target specific areas through evaluation of error patterns on written work. Teaches can also conduct direct observations of students completing word problems to allow for probing students on strategies they are using to solve the problem.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article provides a framework, for special educators in particular, that highlights principles that are important to address for students with learning disabilities and those who struggle in mathematics content. Teaching mathematics to students with learning disabilities or who are at risk for mathematics failure can be difficult and requires a deep, rich knowledge of content, a strong pedagogical foundation, cutting-edge technology skills, and a foundational understanding of the characteristics of diverse learners. Although provision of quality instruction is a crucial component for improving student outcomes, it is one that is challenging, particularly with regard to mathematics. There are many evidence-based, high-quality resources available for teachers to access and use (see Figures 1 and 2). For students to develop the mathematical competencies they need to be prepared, it is essential that they have teachers who plan instruction given the current evidence base and continue their professional development to provide the best possible service.
